ai-mn58:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-mn58:2.1_0: Then Prince Abhaya went to Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta,
ai-mn58:2.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn58:3.1_0: “Come, prince, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.
ai-mn58:3.2_0: Then you will get a good reputation:
ai-mn58:3.3_0: ‘Prince Abhaya refuted the doctrine of the ascetic Gotama, so mighty and powerful!’”
ai-mn58:3.4_0: “But sir, how am I to do this?”
ai-mn58:3.5_0: “Here, prince, go to the ascetic Gotama and say to him:
ai-mn58:3.6_0: ‘Sir, might the Realized One utter speech that is disliked by others?’
ai-mn58:3.7_0: When he’s asked this, if he answers:
ai-mn58:3.9_0: ‘Then, sir, what exactly is the difference between you and an ordinary person?
ai-mn58:3.10_0: For when it comes to that ordinary person’s speech is disliked by others, their disliked by others.’
ai-mn58:3.11_0: When he’s asked this, if he answers:
ai-mn58:3.12_0: ‘He would not, prince,’ say this to him:
ai-mn58:3.13_0: ‘Then, sir, why exactly did you declare of Devadatta:
ai-mn58:3.14_0: “Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable”?
ai-mn58:3.15_0: Devadatta was angry and upset with what you said.’
ai-mn58:3.16_0: When you put this dilemma to him, the Buddha won’t be able to either spit it out or swallow it down.”
ai-mn58:3.17_0: He’ll be like a man with an iron cross stuck in his throat, unable to either spit it out or swallow it down.”
ai-mn58:3.18_0: In the same way, when the ascetic Gotama asked a question, you won’t be able to either spit it out or swallow it down.”
ai-mn58:4.2_0: Then he looked up at the sun and thought,
ai-mn58:4.3_0: “It’s too late to refute the Buddha’s doctrine today.
ai-mn58:4.4_0: I shall refute his doctrine in my own home tomorrow.” He said to the Buddha,
ai-mn58:4.5_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me, together with three other monks.”
ai-mn58:4.6_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-mn58:5.1_0: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Abhaya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-mn58:5.2_0: Then when the night had passed, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Abhaya’s home.
ai-mn58:5.2_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-mn58:5.3_0: Then Abhaya served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-mn58:5.4_0: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Abhaya took a low seat, sat to one side,

ai-mn58:6.4_0: “Then the Jains have lost in this, sir.”

ai-mn58:7.1_0: Now at that time a little baby boy was sitting in Prince Abhaya’s lap.
ai-mn58:7.2_0: Then the Buddha said to Abhaya,
ai-mn58:7.4_0: If—because of your negligence or his nurse’s negligence—your boy was to put a stick or stone in his mouth, what would you do to him?”
ai-mn58:7.5_0: “I’d try to take it out, sir.
ai-mn58:7.6_0: If that didn’t work, I’d hold his head with my left hand, and take it out using a hooked finger of my right hand, even if it drew blood.
ai-mn58:7.8_0: I have compassion for my princes.”
ai-mn58:8.1_0: “In the same way, prince, the Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and harmful, and which is disliked by others.
ai-mn58:8.2_0: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and correct, but which is disliked by others.
ai-mn58:8.3_0: The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, substantive, and beneficial, but which is disliked by others.
ai-mn58:8.4_0: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and harmful, but which is liked by others.
ai-mn58:8.5_0: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and correct, but which is liked by others.
ai-mn58:8.6_0: The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, substantive, and beneficial, and which is liked by others.
ai-mn58:8.8_0: Because the Realized One has compassion for sentient beings.”
ai-mn58:9.1_0: “Sir, there are clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics who come to see you with a question already planned.
ai-mn58:9.2_0: Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer just appear to you on the spot?”
ai-mn58:10.1_0: “Well then, prince, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
ai-mn58:10.3_0: Are you skilled in your chariot?”
ai-mn58:10.6_0: When they come to you and ask:
ai-mn58:10.7_0: ‘What’s the name of this chariot part?’
ai-mn58:10.8_0: Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer just appear to you on the spot?”
ai-mn58:10.9_0: “Sir, I am skilled in the chariot-maker belonging to the chariot.
ai-mn58:10.10_0: All the parts are well-known to me.
ai-mn58:10.11_0: may they spring up on the spot.”
ai-mn58:11.1_0: “In the same way, when clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics come to see me with a question already planned, the answer just appears to me on the spot.
ai-mn58:11.3_0: Because the Realized One is clearly comprehended the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.”
ai-mn58:12.1_0: When he had spoken, Prince Abhaya said to the Buddha,
ai-mn58:12.3_0: who has gone for refuge from today forward for as long as I have the breath of life,”
ai-mn58:12.4_0: The eighth sections on Abhaya is finished.
